text.p: British gilts will remain trapped in a narrow range on Tuesday, confined by strong resistance at 109-08 on the upside, and support at 108-15, technical analysts said.
"Gilts will be stuck in a range with possibly a very marginal upside bias," said Marc Ostwald, technical strategist at London Bond Broking here.
He said the June contract would run into an initial band of resistance at 108-27 to 108-31, an area of old lows.
Charts show the contract hit a daily low of 108-31 on April 9, and one of 108-28 on April 10.
"That band constitutes an area of severe congestion which the market needs to get through to see any further gains," said Ostwald.
He said is the contract pushes up through 108-31 it would soon stall at further resistance at 109-08.
"I'd be more surprised to see that level go -- but if it does, it could go to 109-18, the top of the current range.
The June contract hit a daily high of 109-18 on April 9.
Traders on LIFFE were fairly bullish on the June gilt, citing an initial target of 109-08, followed by 109-23.
By 0705 GMT, the June gilt was up 8/32 at 109-03.
"The market's looking extremely perky -- it met all its targets yesterday, I'm quite bullish," said one LIFFE trader at a British bank.
Charts show 109-23 is a 38 percent retracement of the move from the March 11 high of 112-09 down to the April 1 low of 108-05.
On the downside, Ostwald said congestion at 108-12 to 108-15 was the first support. The contract hit a daily low of 108-12 on April 4, 108-14 on April 14 and 108-15 on April 7.
If that gives way, the next support comes in at 108-05, the cyclical low on April 1, Ostwald said.
"Medium term I'm pretty negative on gilts," said Ostwald. "There's the chance of quite a severe down dip coming up to the election -- after that it could rally."
By 0717 GMT June short sterling was up two basis points at 93.42.
The LIFFE trader said investors were generally short June short sterling, adding the market would aim for 93.48, 93.50.

"There's been a bit of a change in feeling, people are only going for a quarter point rather than a half point rise in UK rates and the producer price index (on Monday) was a lot better than expected," he said.
